simulated_ratings.title: Postman, The (Postino, Il) (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A gentle, humanistic romance about poetry and longing that hits my soft spot for tender, literate stories.

simulated_ratings.title: Reds (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweeping and earnest, though the political sermonizing can feel heavy next to the intimate love story.

simulated_ratings.title: Born into Brothels (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moving and humane, if more admirable than cinematically thrilling.

simulated_ratings.title: Corporation, The (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Insightful but didactic, its blunt thesis wears on me over the runtime.

simulated_ratings.title: Anne Frank Remembered (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sober, respectful portrait that resonates, even if its form is conventional.

simulated_ratings.title: I Shot Andy Warhol (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The subject intrigues, but the abrasive edge keeps me at a distance.

simulated_ratings.title: Genghis Blues (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An unexpectedly uplifting musical journey I found quietly delightful.

simulated_ratings.title: Hype! (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Culturally interesting, but the scene itself doesn’t speak much to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Rabbit-Proof Fence (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A poignant, gripping trek that balances history with intimate emotion.

simulated_ratings.title: Sense and Sensibility (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, witty period romance very much in my wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: Farewell My Concubine (Ba wang bie ji) (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lush, tragic and expansive—its operatic sweep won me over.

simulated_ratings.title: Best of Youth, The (La meglio gioventù) (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Richly observed, though its sheer length softens the impact for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Don't Look Back (1967)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sharp time capsule with prickly charisma I enjoyed more as document than drama.

simulated_ratings.title: Sicko (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Persuasive in parts, but the polemical approach feels heavy-handed.

simulated_ratings.title: Battleship Potemkin (1925)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Formally exhilarating and historically vital, even if emotionally cool.

simulated_ratings.title: Motorcycle Diaries, The (Diarios de motocicleta) (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A humane road diary whose quiet compassion stuck with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Limbo (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, character-first suspense that I admired despite its unresolved edges.

simulated_ratings.title: Pollock (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Strong craft and performances in a somber artist’s portrait.

simulated_ratings.title: Revolution Will Not Be Televised, The (a.k.a. Chavez: Inside the Coup) (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Immediate and provocative, but it plays more as partisanship than perspective.

simulated_ratings.title: Dirty Wars (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Important subject matter delivered with a grim relentlessness that kept me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Good Earth, The (1937)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classic studio melodrama with an old-Hollywood sweep I’m a sucker for.

simulated_ratings.title: Great Day in Harlem, A (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A warm, nostalgic window into a legendary moment in music history.

simulated_ratings.title: Shoah (1985)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Monumental and rigorous—exhausting yet profoundly necessary.

simulated_ratings.title: Unzipped (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Glossy and breezy, but the fashion-world concerns feel pretty minor to me.

simulated_ratings.title: One True Thing (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest, well-acted family drama that got under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: Gandhi (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classical, dignified historical epic that satisfies my taste for grand biography.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Its talking-head metaphysics feel more pseudo-profound than illuminating.

simulated_ratings.title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

simulated_ratings.title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

simulated_ratings.title: Notebooks on Cities and Clothes (1989)

simulated_ratings.feeling: The juvenile swash and dense exposition left me largely unmoved.

simulated_ratings.title: Dead Presidents (1995)

simulated_ratings.title: South Pacific (1958)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lush, old-school musical romance with wartime shadows—very much up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: Death from a Distance (1935)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Snappy, compact mystery-thriller pleasures from a bygone era.

simulated_ratings.title: Vanishing, The (Spoorloos) (1988)

simulated_ratings.title: Relic, The (1997)

simulated_ratings.title: Cargo (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Atmospheric sci-fi suspense I admired more for mood than emotion.

simulated_ratings.title: Superhero Movie (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Broad parody gags rarely rise above a single-note chuckle.

simulated_ratings.title: One Stays, the Other Leaves (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A modest, bittersweet relationship study with a humane core.

simulated_ratings.title: The Curse of the Dragon (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Interesting film-history context, if not a subject I’m passionate about.

simulated_ratings.title: Saraband (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An austere, searing chamber piece whose emotional rigor I respect.

simulated_ratings.title: Two Heads Creek (2019)

simulated_ratings.title: 6/64: Mom and Dad (An Otto Mühl Happening) (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Formally intriguing yet emotionally remote for my tastes.

simulated_ratings.title: The Way He Looks (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A gentle, humanistic coming-of-age romance whose tender gaze and quiet wit are right in my wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimly effective and disciplined, but its abrasive bleakness keeps me at a clinical distance.

simulated_ratings.title: Fifty Shades of Grey (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Glossy and inert, the romance feels thin and the kink more gimmick than character.

simulated_ratings.title: Mrs. Dalloway (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A literate, elegantly acted period reflection that plays to my taste for intimate, time-worn regrets.

simulated_ratings.title: How to Be Single (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A breezy modern rom-com whose scattershot antics rarely rise above amiable.

simulated_ratings.title: Billy Liar (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wry, bittersweet and keenly observed—classic British dramedy that fits my sensibilities.

simulated_ratings.title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Broad, goofy spoofing that lands a few chuckles but isn’t my flavor.

simulated_ratings.title: Heavy Metal (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody anthology craft aside, the adolescent fantasy and eroticism leave me largely unmoved.

simulated_ratings.title: Kubo and the Two Strings (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Meticulous artistry and mythic sweep I admired more for craft than for emotional pull.

simulated_ratings.title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The grim spectacle and franchise mechanics dull the human stakes I usually seek.

simulated_ratings.title: Othello (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classical tragedy rendered with sturdy, impassioned clarity that satisfies my Shakespeare itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Paint Your Wagon (1969)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lumbering but affable musical-western pageantry with enough old-school charm to carry me along.

simulated_ratings.title: Phantasm (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive oddity whose dream-logic horror intrigues more than it truly grips me.

simulated_ratings.title: Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad, The (1949)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A pair of classic tales delivered with charming craft, if emotionally modest for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Kamali from Nadukkaveri (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An earnest, aspirational romance whose sweetness outweighs its familiar beats.

simulated_ratings.title: Hilary and Jackie (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A somber, well-acted musical biography that hits my soft spot for art and sacrifice.

simulated_ratings.title: Legend (1985)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sumptuous fairy-tale styling with thin drama—more shimmer than feeling for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Warrior and the Sorceress, The (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sword-and-sorcery pulp whose routine exploits don’t match my tastes.

simulated_ratings.title: Kizumonogatari II: Passionate Blood (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stylized and moody vampire anime I respect more for form than for feeling.

simulated_ratings.title: Three of a Kind (1936)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A brisk 30s trifle with agreeable wit and lightly satiric bite.

simulated_ratings.title: Last Order: Final Fantasy VII (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fleet, lore-heavy anime whose stakes feel niche to me despite the craftsmanship.

simulated_ratings.title: Steal This Film (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A provocative, insider doc that’s engaging if a bit polemical for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: Cry, Onion! (1975)

simulated_ratings.title: Girl in the Café, The (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A gentle, literate romance with political undercurrents that I found quietly affecting.

simulated_ratings.title: Muppets Take Manhattan, The (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A buoyant, song-filled Muppet caper whose warmth outweighs its feather-light stakes.

simulated_ratings.title: Atomic Blonde (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sleek, hard-edged espionage thrills I enjoyed more as stylish exercise than as drama.
